snippet.textDisplay: It depends on the size and resources the game use, technically if it can reach 8k, I dont think it will be for large large titles that use alot resources, it  might be for more major smaller titles that use less. I believe most games will just be 4k, unless the game developers decides anything higher or lower. I mean a game that is smaller and aims for 8k 120hz might be right in the ball park, but a huge ass game that is a beast might only reach 4k, and if it did reach 8k it might be limited to below 120hz unless they pulled off some magic trick.
snippet.textOriginal: It depends on the size and resources the game use, technically if it can reach 8k, I dont think it will be for large large titles that use alot resources, it  might be for more major smaller titles that use less. I believe most games will just be 4k, unless the game developers decides anything higher or lower. snippet.textDisplay:
X-Cloud utilization of the users home Xbox as a streaming platform is basically Sony's Remote play.

I can play my PS4 games at 1080p on my phone over Verizon's 4G network without a problem. I can also use my cellphone as a mobile hotspot and play my PS4 games on my PS Vita. 

So, given the above I can completely see being able to play your Xbox games over mobile 4G connection and X-Cloud.
snippet.textOriginal:
X-Cloud utilization of the users home Xbox as a streaming platform is basically Sony's Remote play.

I can play my PS4 games at 1080p on my phone over Verizon's 4G network without a problem. I can also use my cellphone as a mobile hotspot and play my PS4 games on my PS Vita. 

So, given the above I can completely see being able to play your Xbox games over mobile 4G connection and X-Cloud.

snippet.textDisplay: Microsoft shows it like tech progress is going better than ever before but in actuality, the opposite is true. AMD Navi has not even doubled performance per watt or per dollar after 3 long years since Polaris or PS4 Pro. There is no way to support AAA games in 8K or in 4K 120 frames per second. Even 4K 60fps will be very difficult to achieve (but possible with superb optimization).
snippet.textOriginal: Microsoft shows it like tech progress is going better than ever before but in actuality, the opposite is true. AMD Navi has not even doubled performance per watt or per dollar after 3 long years since Polaris or PS4 Pro. There is no way to support AAA games in 8K or in 4K 120 frames per second. Even 4K 60fps will be very difficult to achieve (but possible with superb optimization).

snippet.textDisplay:
For what it's worth, Spencer said they are working with television manufactures. That explains the 8K to me. Expect video to be 8K and games to run at what 1080 or 4K. 

Serving content from your local machine will be local streaming. They already support this with Win10 and Xbone. Xcloud will be from Azure servers. That is most likely the reason behind the hybrid streaming naming.

To me this is just a continuation of the Xbox one platform in much the same way Vista had evolved into Win10. The peripherals will even move with you to the next console.
snippet.textOriginal:
For what it's worth, Spencer said they are working with television manufactures. That explains the 8K to me. Expect video to be 8K and games to run at what 1080 or 4K. 

Serving content from your local machine will be local streaming. They already support this with Win10 and Xbone. Xcloud will be from Azure servers. That is most likely the reason behind the hybrid streaming naming.

To me this is just a continuation of the Xbox one platform in much the same way Vista had evolved into Win10. The peripherals will even move with you to the next console.

snippet.textDisplay: Let's think about it for a moment. This gen was "4k 60fps" - that actually meant 60fps at 1080p and 30fps at 4k. It'll be the same for next time around, with 4k 60fps if we're lucky, but I highly doubt we'll see 8k 120fps concurrently. More like 120fps at 1440p and 60fps at 8k. Again, if you're lucky.
snippet.textOriginal: Let's think about it for a moment. This gen was "4k 60fps" - that actually meant 60fps at 1080p and 30fps at 4k. It'll be the same for next time around, with 4k 60fps if we're lucky, but I highly doubt we'll see 8k 120fps concurrently. More like 120fps at 1440p and 60fps at 8k. Again, if you're lucky.

snippet.textDisplay: 8K doesn't mean games will use that resolution or will run at 120 fps. It means the console will SUPPORT that. So if an indie developer makes a 2D game with nothing but colorful drawings, it could run at even 8K or 120 fps if he wants. But 99% of the games obviously won't as it's not even needed (no one has an 8K TV anyway). But the support is there, should someone want to go over 4K or 60 fps. That's all.
snippet.textOriginal: 8K doesn't mean games will use that resolution or will run at 120 fps. It means the console will SUPPORT that. So if an indie developer makes a 2D game with nothing but colorful drawings, it could run at even 8K or 120 fps if he wants. But 99% of the games obviously won't as it's not even needed (no one has an 8K TV anyway). But the support is there, should someone want to go over 4K or 60 fps. That's all.
